nPONmjSS.question: The accuracy of the, manually calculated, DR-position of an aircraft is, among other things, affected by:

options.text: the accuracy of the forecasted wind.
the accuracy of the adjustment of the position lines for the motion of the aircraft between the last fix and the DR-position.
the accuracy of the adjustment of the position lines for the motion of the aircraft between the last and the new DR-position.
the accuracy of the actual wind.

s8lF9nwV.question:
At 10:00 UTC an aircraft departs position A 51°30'N, 001°59'W and flies on a track of 270° at a GS of 390 kt. 
 What is the aircraft's position at 11:30 UTC

2XLFsRoy.question: Isogonic lines connect positions that have:

options.text: the same angle of magnetic dip.

dAdfoVE7.question:
In winter time, a VFR flight is planned. Which of the following ground features should be used for orientation?
1. Coastline. 
 2. Big lakes. 
 3. Farmland in the countryside. 
 4. High radio mast. 
 5. Railway line.

f7xdNyFh.question:
Consider the following factors that determine the accuracy of a DR position
	
1) the flight time since the last position update.
2) the accuracy of the forecasted wind.
3) the accuracy of the TAS.
4) the accuracy of the steered heading.
Using the list above which of the following contains the most complete answer?

Rluijx7D.question: A pilot is planning a VFR flight across steep, mountainous terrain. Due to airspace restrictions, the flight will be relatively low above the terrain. Restrictions in VFR navigation in such circumstances can include...

options.text: a shorter time to see navigation features on the near side of valleys, compared to when flying over a flat landscape.
poor visibility in the valleys when the flight is taking place at mid-day.
a shorter visual range for navigation features that are down slope, compared to the visual range for similar features situated on flat land.
difficulty in identifying navigation features that are situated on ridges.

l4s0Eaoo.question: You are flying over a snowy area. What is the danger about power lines?

options.text: Dangerous if crossing a valley, but safe along a ridge.
Not dangerous as they're always indicated on the chart.
Always safe as they're easily identified.
Dangerous along a ridge, but safe if crossing a valley.

3N4w0jhU.question: Consider the following factors that determine the accuracy of a DR position: 1.  The flight time since the last position update.2.  The accuracy of the forecasted wind.3.  The accuracy of the TAS.4.  The accuracy of the steered heading. Using the list which of the above statements are correct ?

0bBbPTXE.question:
What will be the revised ETA (to the nearest minute) overhead turning point B in the following situation?  Assume that all other conditions remain unchanged.
Planned ETA over turning point B: 14:14.
Planned distance from turning point A to turning point B: 43NM.
Planned distance from turning point A to check feature X: 10 NM.
Actual time overhead check feature X: 1 minute 15 seconds late.

iEgcedDH.question: The purpose of establishing a grid is

options.text: to provide a system for directions where a great circle has a constant direction, even if its true direction varies.
minimise the errors introduced when making calculations involving variation.
to make the system of latitude and longitude available on a gridded map.
make a chart covering high latitudes that has the same qualities as the equatorial Mercator chart.

2toxj9Td.question: In a VFR cross-country flight, a landmark is spotted on a relative bearing of 45° left of the aircraft’s nose. Three minutes later the same landmark is observed on a relative bearing of 90° left of the aircraft’s nose. If the TAS is 90 kt and there is a tailwind of 30 kt, what is the distance to the landmark at the time of the second bearing?

wwTqkgnh.question:
Which of the factors named hereafter should be considered by the pilot when selecting landmarks as visual reference points? 
1. Possibility of identification 
2. Transmitted frequency 
3. Visibility
4. Closeness to the track

vINbcAJh.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints and you get lost. What should you do?

options.text: Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure.
Proceed and turn at the next checkpoint based on time.

uPAWDwE9.question: An aircraft is flying a VFR flight at a low level over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints. What action by the pilot is recommended?

options.text: Proceed and turn at the next checkpoint based on time.

1G8E0G7t.question: Levels curve on a hypsometric chart refer to:

options.text: When the terrain is covered with snow and the horizon blends with the sky, visual determination of height becomes difficult.
When taking-off from a snow-covered lake.
In flight conditions when you suddenly enter a cloud and everything "gets white" outside the cockpit windows.

5p5AtwZn.question:
When flying a VFR map-reading exercise, the pilot becomes lost because of isolated patches of fog hindering the ability to accurately pin-point his/her position. Which of the following should the pilot do in this situation ?

1. Maintain visual contact with the ground. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. 3. Fly a series of expanding circles to find a suitable check point. 4. Look at the terrain for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, railway, river or coastline. 5. Map read from map to ground.

5X7rosDK.question: You have planned a VFR trip by day but you changed it to fly at night due to an improvement of the weather. What do you have to be careful of?

options.text: Not recognizing the aerodrome by the light colors.
Not being able to see the populated areas with or without lights.
Missing the visual references chosen for the daytime flight.

InDHwCra.question: A pilot is flying under VFR. Which VFR navigation technique will allow a pilot to maximise the amount of time he/she can use to check for other traffic and also maintain good situational awareness?

options.text: Delay any aircraft system checks until the aircraft is turned onto a new heading.
Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track.
Keep a continuous update of the position by looking within a short distance of the aircraft.
Plan to fly from point to point as identified on the map and then on the ground.

FDufXFOG.question: When selecting landmarks as visual reference points, a pilot should consider the following factors: - Transmission frequency - Possibility of identification - Closeness to the track - Visibility

7bGSzx0M.question: An aircraft is making a VFR cross-country flight at low level. The flight involves at least four visual checkpoints on the route. Which option indicates the most suitable types of checkpoint?

options.text: Look for distinctive features such as a railway line to lead into a checkpoint.
Fly as low as possible and select aerodromes that are active for parachuting and gliding.
Choose large, built-up areas that can be seen easily from low level.
If flying over a wet, lowland area, choose small lakes rather than large ones.

b08WQoSx.question: A pilot is flying VFR in VMC at 1 500 ft above ground, passing small separated villages. The pilot chose a church tower in such village as a turning point for a new course. After completing the turn and flying towards the next waypoint, which is shown on the chart as a framework tower, the pilot is not able to find this tower at the expected time overhead. What is a likely reason for this navigation error?

options.text: The pilot changed course at a wrong village.
It is hard to recognize church towers in villages.
The vertical visibility was not sufficient to recognize the waypoints.
The framework tower is hidden behind buildings of the same height.

vizWLDLB.question: According to ICAO Annex 4, what kind of colour should contour lines on aeronautical charts have?

86z1LjxZ.question:
Refer to VFR Chart ED-4 from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. 
 You are planning a VFR flight during the day from Dingolfing aerodrome EDPD (N48°40', E12°30') to Arnbruck aerodrome EDNB (N49°08', E012°59'). What is the best visual checkpoint that should be used en-route to check the flight progress?

options.text: The intersection of the multi-lane roads A3 and A92.
The unlighted obstacle 2 NM North off Deggendorf.
The lighted obstacle 6 NM South off Deggendorf.
The heliport at the North part of Straubing.

9jbsHguD.question: Which one of the following below may reduce the visibility for an aircraft performing a low level VFR flight on a day with clear sky?

options.text: Man-made obstacle ahead of the aircraft.

kzvBMJd0.question: Which one of the following below may reduce the visibility for an aircraft performing a low level VFR flight on a day with clear sky?

options.text: Flying downwind of factories producing smoke.
Sun is high in the sky.
Flying with the sun behind the aircraft.

fB5WMuLF.question: When wanting to check flight progress by observation of a single visual position line (e.g. a canal) the latter must be

options.text: more or less perpendicular to the track.
more or less parallel to the track.

INPRdtdT.question: A pilot desires to check the progress of his flight by observation of a single visual position line (e.g., a canal). This line must be:

options.text: more or less perpendicular to the track.
more or less parallel to the track.

RGlLiJ7X.question: On a VFR flight during night, which one of the following has to be considered by a pilot most carefully?

options.text: Terrain and obstacles along an approach may not be clearly visible.
When looking outside at lit objects, it can cause disorientation with respect to the instrument readings.
Use of red lights in the cockpit can cause temporary blindness for pilots.
The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated.

j5SSVck8.question: Which of the following would be the best fixes for a VFR cross country flight over an NOT built up area in order to check for any drifting error along the track? - Four-lane road crossing perpendicularly the intended track. - Four-lane road crossing a river close to the intended track. - Double-lane road crossing the river close to the intended track. - Disused railway line crossing a river close to the intended track. Choose the correct combination.

Uwj55g5r.question: Following a heavy snow storm, which of the following visual references would be the appropriate choices? - Open fields - Railroad tracks - A river - A coastline - A high tower - Lit aerodrome lights Choose the correct grouping.

Yt42FDui.question: The best visual marking for a VFR flight on a warm summer day is:

options.text: A village on the edge of a larger city.
A grass airfield in the country side.

ysTBbQRB.question: Which are the best visual landmarks in a VFR flight? - Large water features. - Agricultural farm land. - Exceptionally high obstacles. - Electricity power lines. - Isolated towns.

H9kUNOd0.question: While planning a flight on a clear, moon-lit night under VFR and deciding on what visual navigation features to use, a pilot should consider that...

options.text: colour differences will be very difficult to identify.
roads, including busy ones, are difficult to see.
narrow rivers are easy to see.
visibility is worst when flying in the direction of (towards) the moon.

Hq18n8w9.question: When selecting en-route navigational visual checkpoints during flight planning, which of the following is not a general consideration?

glE1jY1m.question:
For this question use the VFR chart ED-4 from the Jeppesen GSPRM 2017.  
A pilot is planning for a VFR cross-country flight from aerodrome Arnbruck (EDNB) (N49° 07.5 E012° 59.1') to aerodrome Vilshofen (EDMV) (N48° 38.1', E013° 11.7'), using visual checkpoints.  What feature is situated at N48° 40', E013° 06'?

options.text: A lighted man- made cooling tower.

1OQW7ess.question: Relief is usually portrayed by combinations of: - Contour lines - Shading - Frequencies - Colours - Spot heights - Graduated scale

7MF8hZ5E.question:
Which of the following are problems associated with VFR navigation (without GPS) over low-lying desert late in the morning at about 11 AM?
1. Good navigation features might be widely separated.
2. Visual range is likely to be restricted.
3. Maps might be incomplete or out-of-date.
4. Visibility into the Sun might be difficult due to glare.

oY6HvUD3.question: During a low level VFR flight at 600 ft AGL, which one of the following challenges may be faced by the pilot?

options.text: It might NOT be easy to recognise visual waypoints, so he/she could fly past them.
Vertical features disappear in the surrounding environment and are difficult to spot.
Open areas are much easier to identify than built-up areas.
Terrain contours are more difficult to spot compared to when flying at a high altitude.

EgKzxgyC.question:
Which of the following features are the most useful for VFR navigation by day?
1. Tall masts,
2. Large lakes
3. Streets in a large town
4. Area with several small woods
5. Active power station.

5K7hYAF1.question: Which features are the most suitable when flying a VFR flight at low level during the daylight, using checkpoints on a 1:500 000 map?

options.text: Ones that are tall and prominent, such as towers.
Small ones, such as individual houses distributed over an area of farmland.
Minor roads in a built up area.
Very large ones, such as an extensive wooded area.

Dr33zse7.question: What should a pilot pay special attention to when planning a VFR night flight?

options.text: The reduced ability to identify colors at night.
Even high-traffic roads may not be easily identifiable.
It is difficult to determine the flight path of other traffic.
The position of the moon due to reflecting light inhibiting visibility.

ymCSQTpm.question: What is a visual check point?

options.text: A position on the surface of the Earth visually seen that coincides with the position on a chart.
A position on the surface of the Earth with visual contact of the runway.

lPczZbXN.question: When a pilot operates a VFR cross-country flight during the day in a mountainous region at low altitudes, due to ATC restrictions, what should a pilot be aware of?

options.text: Visual references will be visible for a limited period of time.
Inability to identify visual references, placed near mountain ridges.

Sc39TxlV.question: A pilot has planned a VFR trip by day but he/she changed it to fly at night due to an improvement of the weather. What does he/she have to be careful of?

options.text: The chosen fixes may not be clearly visible.
Not reckoning aerodromes due to weak, coloured lights.
Missing fixes the pilot planned to have reference by visual contact.

znXAMoRc.question: What do you understand by the term "whiteout"?

options.text: When the terrain is covered with snow and the horizon blends with the sky, visual determination of height becoming difficult.
Flight conditions when you suddenly enter a cloud and everything "gets white" outside the cockpit windows.
Taking off from a snow-covered lake.

RUxtd0ME.question: During a low level flight, 2 parallel roads that are crossed at right angles by an aircraft. The time between these roads can be used to check the aircraft

MhOuYiPo.question: A VFR flight is planned with a chart whose scale is 1:500 000. The ground feature which should be used for orientation is/are:

RKyZIg1G.question: A pilot is planning a VFR flight which crosses a controlled airspace. Because of restrictions of the controlled airspace, part of the flight must be flown at a low level. Which of the following is a problem of navigation at low level that could be faced in a VFR flight?

options.text: Visual range to the horizon is restricted at low level.
Navigation features can be noticed more easily, but are more difficult to identify.
The feeling that you are flying more slowly over the ground changes how you perceive distance.
Features with great vertical extent are harder to see.

zOQlimat.question: Which of the following is not a general consideration when selecting en-route navigational visual check points during flight planning?

options.text: Working from large features to small features.

rAK3z9Op.question: When contour lines on a VFR chart are very close together, this means that the terrain is...

9n0NpmZm.question:
The following features are the most useful for VFR navigation by day:1. Tall masts 
 2. Large lakes 
 3. Streets in a large town 
 4. Area with several small woods 
 5. Active power station

037v8PFe.question: Transferring position lines (LOP) An aircraft should follow a true course 120° , given TAS 100 kts and W/V 360/50. It obtains position lines at 1400, 1403, 1406 hours.

options.text: 1 LOP is transferred by 11.6 NM, 1 LOP by 5.8 NM, the third one is not transferred.
1 LOP is transferred by 8.0 NM, 1 LOP by 4.0 NM, the third one is not transferred.
1 LOP is transferred by 10.0 NM, 1 LOP by 5.0 NM, the third one is not transferred.
1 LOP is transferred by 12.5 NM, 1 LOP by 6.25 NM, the third one is not transferred.

Hd27x7of.question: Which are the greatest dangers when flying VFR over a low lying desert area without a GPS at 11 a.m.? - Good navigation features may be widely spread. - Visibility may be degraded. - The maps may be out of date or incomplete. - Visibility into sun may be difficult due to glare.

wTXoa17s.question:
When planning a VFR flight, the selection of the navigation features that are suitable for transferring from map to ground is required. What ground features are particularly important for VFR navigation?
1. Large water features,  
2. Agricultural farm land,  
3. Exceptionally high obstacles,  
4. Telephone lines,  
5. Isolated towns.

qPNuc6vF.question: Which option describes the greatest potential threat for VFR navigation at night?

options.text: If the aircraft deviates from the planned route, natural obstacles excluded during the planning stage could be a threat as they could be difficult to see.
During outside scan using peripheral vision, illuminated obstacles appear as being further away than they actually are, giving the impression that there is adequate avoidance time.
Due to the specific wavelength of the colour red, lit obstacles are difficult to identify, increasing the potential for a collision.
Location of aerodromes CANNOT be easily identified unless flying overhead, due to low lighting intensity.

XQLks06a.question: Which option describes the greatest potential threat for VFR navigation at night?

options.text: The aircraft height during an approach can be easily misjudged due to insufficient external visual cues.
Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness.
It is difficult to determine the flight direction of other aircraft unless their landing lights are on.
When external lighting provides good visual cues,flying by cross-reference to instruments may cause spatial disorientation.

AblwYRoQ.question: A pilot is flying VFR and is about to conduct an approach to an unfamiliar airfield just after the sunrise. What should he/she pay extra attention to?

options.text: The duration of the morning civil twilight.

C9sZuvbY.question: Contour lines on aeronautical maps and charts connect points

RH93bAkn.question: During visual navigation in freezing conditions, after heavy snowfall, which of the following landmarks will give the best reference for a visual checkpoint?

Yfozo60f.question: During visual navigation in freezing conditions, after heavy snowfall, which of the following landmarks will give the best reference for a visual checkpoint?

U7dLI6ol.question: During visual navigation in freezing conditions, after heavy snowfall, which of the following landmark will give the best reference for a visual checkpoint?

8iAGTrzv.question: The best ground feature to check track deviation while flying on a heading 360º is:

options.text: A large river in a North-South orientation.
A railway in an East-West orientation.

lwvkprg1.question:
The evaluation of the differences between DR (dead reckoned) positions and actual positions (fixes) can refine flight performance and navigation. Which of the following factors affect the accuracy of a DR position?
  1. The accuracy of the last positive fix
  2. The accuracy with which heading has been maintained
  3. The accuracy with which air speed has been maintained
  4. The accuracy of our estimate of the wind affecting the aircraft
NOTE: This is an example question designed to reflect a particular 2018 LO and has not been reported as having been seen in this form in an exam.

rDtAJD5b.question: Which of the following ground features would be the most suitable to use for VFR navigation?NOTE: This is an example question designed to reflect a particular 2018 LO and has not been reported as having been seen in this form in an exam.

options.text: A large factory with twin chimneys located by a large river in open countryside 1 NM to the right of your planned track
A small lake in a valley which crosses your track at right angles
One of several small gravel extraction sites close to each other 5 NM to the left of your track
A Y-shaped railway junction 2NM left of your track with a ridge of high ground between your track and the junction

vB9I7ba5.question: Identifying landmarks and overall orientation and visualisation of the inflight situation on a VFR flight can be made easy by:

options.text: Holding a relevant part of the map with track-up orientation.
Holding only a small part of the map with North-up orientation.
Holding the complete map with North-up orientation.
Holding the complete map with track-up orientation.

CJl3jzKi.question:
During a low level flight two parallel roads are crossed at right angles by an aircraft
What can the time taken between the road crossing be used to check?

jDHsFmZp.question: What is the best visual reporting point for an aircraft flying a VFR flight above a hilly area?

options.text: Few small rivers that leave a big river.

7Y6Uu2hl.question: With regards to visual navigation, you are flying over land the is covered in snow with no visual features.  You should...

options.text: turn at  the time expected overhead the next waypoint.
turn around 180 and return the way you came.
climb and commence the lost procedure.

Z0ujYJDz.question: What is the best ground feature to check the track deviation for a north-south flight?

options.text: A river in a north-south direction.
A railroad running from east to west.
An east to west power line.

Vq6Z4trZ.question: You are flying VFR low level over a snowy area with no ground references. What do you do?

options.text: Proceed and turn at the next checkpoint based on time.
Climb to a higher level and initiate lost procedure.

hDEuvjex.question: During visual navigation in freezing conditions, after heavy snowfall, which of the following landmark will give the best reference for a visual checkpoint

HU2wkTF9.question: A pilot is planning for a VFR cross-country flight, using visual checkpoints. Which of the following would be the most suitable checkpoint?

options.text: A feature that contrasts with its natural surroundings.
A feature that merges into its natural surroundings.
A valley in an area of low hills.
A small lake in a mountainous region.

T6SovYMl.question: <div>What is a factor to consider when planning a visual approach to an unfamiliar aerodrome just after sunrise?

options.text: The location of the aerodrome reference point.

geNTJIqR.question: Which of the following ground features should allow a Pilot flying along a VFR track to best check for any time deviation?

options.text: A double-lane road crossing your intended track.
A double-lane road crossing a lake close to your intended track.
A single-lane road crossing a lake close to your intended track.
A double-lane road crossing a railway close to your intended track.

jrMuOFnR.question: What will be the risk if a night VFR flight navigates out of the studied route?

options.text: Obstacles may be present in an area not studied before the flight
Obstacles marked on the chart in red may not be seen if you are using a red wavelength light/torch
Airports may be difficult to identify due to their lighting

2r3BPfRP.question: What will be the risk if a night VFR flight navigates out of the studied route?

options.text: The presence of obstacles in the area not studied before the flight.
The obstacles seem to be closer.
The airport can not be identified due to lighting.
The obstacles marked with red light due to red wavelength.

h3ZrQVXM.question: What is the greatest potential threat for VFR navigation at night?

options.text: The aircraft height during an approach can be easily misjudged due to insufficient external visual cues.
It is difficult to determine the flight direction of other aircraft unless their landing lights are on.
Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness.
When external lighting provides good visual cues, flying by cross-reference to instruments may cause spatial disorientation.

AhuFHCKe.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints. What should you do?

options.text: Turn at DR point to next leg.
Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure.

rTjImgni.question: When flying a day VFR flight at low level, using checkpoints on a 1 : 500 000 map, the most suitable features are...

options.text: ones that are tall and prominent, such as towers.
small ones, such a individual houses distributed over an area of farmland.
very large ones, such as an extensive wooded area.
minor roads in a bulit up area.

dQiCFuuc.question: A pilot is flying a VFR map-reading exercise and becomes lost because of isolated fog patches hampering the ability to locate accurately his/her position. Which of the following actions should the pilot take in this situation? - Maintain visual contact with the terrain. - Contact with an ATC unit to request assistance. - Fly a series of expanding circles until finding a significant landmark. - Search on the ground for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, a railway, a river or a coastline. - Map read from map to ground.

BnHHUF52.question:
When flying VFR by day in early summer over part of central Europe, you have been busy looking at the scenery and NOT concentrating on where exactly you are.What are the features which would be suitable for you to set your heading towards, when unsure of your position?
1. A motorway 
 2. A junction of two small roads. 
 3. A railway. 
 4. A river. 
 5. A coastline 
 6. A fruit farm.

CbhLfu2s.question: In a chart with closely spaced contour lines, the slope is...

ri6GehKA.question: During a VFR flight you are a few minutes behind schedule and you are low on fuel. What is the appropriate action for a piston engine airplane?

options.text: Turn before the turning point scheduled and fly direct to the destination.
Fly to a lower altitude to increase the TAS and decrease the HWC.
Make an emergency landing at the nearest suitable field.
Orbit and contact ATC to receive further instructions.

0EoiT7Oo.question: The pilot of a piston-engined aeroplane, flying a VFR flight and approaching to the last turning point, realizes that he/she is both a few minutes behind schedule and low on fuel. What is the appropriate action that should be taken?

options.text: Turn before the scheduled turning point and fly directly to the destination.
Orbit and contact ATC to receive further instructions.
Fly to a lower altitude to increase the TAS and decrease the HWC.
Make an emergency landing at the nearest suitable field.

2v9mbARt.question: How is layer tinting used to define elevation on a chart?

options.text: Different colours indicate ranges of elevation, between defined limits.
Different colours indicate specific steepness of elevation.
Different colours indicate points of equal elevation.
Different colours indicate the change from land to water features.

qsZubsXx.question: How is layer tinting used to define elevation on a chart?

options.text: Different colours indicate ranges of elevation, between defined limits
Different colours indicate the change from land to water features
Different colours indicate specific steepness of elevation
Different colours indicate points of equal elevation

qx2Apzje.question: What feature is shown on the chart at position N54°17' W010° 05'

options.text: the lines of position are transferred at ground speed.
the lines of position are transferred at TAS effective.
the lines of position are transferred at TAS.
the lines of position are transferred TAS effective plus wind speed.

An aircraft follows a coastline during a particular time
This coastline is

A pilot is planning a VFR cross-country flight from aerodrome Arnbruck (EDNB) (N49° 07.5, E012° 59.1') to aerodrome Vilshofen (EDMV) (N48° 38.1', E013° 11.7'), using visual reference checkpoints. What does the feature situated at N48° 40', E013° 06' represent?

Refer to figure 061-22.
Which figures show a cliff and a mountain pass?

xhSqGBET.question: When the contour lines are closer together, the slope is...

c7pyyn7r.question:
Refer to figure 061-36.
Which of the aeronautical chart symbols indicates an RVR observation site?
